Dehydration Gaisbock syndrome is the term ascribed to several conditions initially observed by Felix Gaisbock, in 1905 when he described a group of hypertensive male patients who had high hematocrit levels, normal leukocyte counts, and no splenomegaly A specific type of relative polycythemia is Gaisböck syndrome. A reduction in plasma volume, resulting in (amongst other changes) a relative increase in red blood cell count. RBC mass is normal Gaisbock syndrome (also known as stress or spurious erythrocytosis or spurious polycythemia ) is a syndrome in which polycythemia is ascribed to a contraction of plasma volume Risk factors are hypertension( major risk factor), diuretic therapy, male sex, obesity and smoking.

questions.text: IPSS uses three "prognostic indicators" to predict the course of the patient's disease: The percentage of leukemic blast cells in the marrow, The type of chromosomal changes, if any, in the marrow cells (cytogenetics). International Prognostic scoring system (IPSS) is used in which of the following conditions:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Myelodysplastic syndrome Three Current Scoring Systems for Estimating Prognosis in PMF Patients RISK FACTOR IPSS (2009) DIPSS (2010) DIPSS PLUS (2011) Anemia (<10 g/dL) X X X Leukocytosis (>25,000/µL) X X X Peripheral blood blasts (21%) X X X Constitutional symptoms X X X Age (>65 years) X X X Unfavorable karyotype X Platelet count (<100,000/µL) X Transfusion dependence X

Extraedge:

The Dynamic International Prognostic Scoring System (DIPSS) was developed to determine if the International Prognostic Scoring System (IPSS) risk factors identified as important for survival at the time of primary myelofibrosis (PMF) diagnosis could also be used for risk stratification One point is assigned to each risk factor for IPSS scoring. For DIPSS, the same is true, but anemia is assigned 2 points. The DIPSS Plus scoring system represents a recognition that the addition of unfavorable karyotype, thrombocytopenia, and transfusion dependence improved the DIPSS risk stratification system for which additional points are assigned (Table 103-5). More recent studies suggest that mutational analysis of the ASXL1, EZH2, SRSF2, and IDH1/2 genes further improves risk stratification for survival and leukemic transformation, as can cytogenetic abnormalities. These prognostic scoring systems are not accurate for risk assessment in polycythemia vera or essential thrombocytosis patients who have developed myelofibrosis.

questions.text: A 21 year old male patient undergoing a routine check-up before joining college. His lab investigation revealed the following- Hb- 17g/dl; Hct- 49%; TLC- 5500/mm3, PLT- 2,00,000/uL. When asked about any complaints, he told the doctor that he often has intense itching after taking a shower. Which of the following is the next step in investigating this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

EPO LEVEL In the given clinical scenario, the patient has symptoms of aquagenic pruritus with lab findings showing increased hemoglobin and Hct. To rule out the secondary causes of polycythemia, erythropoietin level is required, it will be low in polycythemia, while it will be raised in secondary causes of polycythemoa We need to evaluate the person for polycythemia if there is- Increased hemoglobin >16.5 g/dl in men or >16 g/dl in women. Increased hematocrit >49 % in men or >48 % in women.

questions.text: You were posted in the OPD as an intern with the junior resident where a patient presented with the following appearance as given below. Her lab investigation revealed - Hb- 17.5 gm/dl, Hct- 48%, TLC- 5,600/mm3, PLT- 1, 70,000 /u L. Which of the following will be true regarding RBC mass, plasma volume and EPO levels if the patient is to be diagnosed with polycythemia vera?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased, increased, decreased. In the given clinical scenario, the patient shows facial plethora, as well as lab investigation, shows elevated Hb and Hct. For the diagnosis, the plasma vol, RBC mass and EPO level will be – Plasma volume- increased RBC mass- increased EPO level- decreased

Highyeild:

Erythrocytosis can be absolute or relative—Differentiation is by RBC mass Absolute polycythemia can be primary (due to normal or low EPO)-Polycythemia Rubra Vera Secondary–Due to increased EPO production due to cortical peritubular interstitial fibroblasts. Relative polycythemia vera- increased EPO level, decreased plasma volume and RBC mass normal. This is also called Gaisbock syndrome. seen in dehydration and post-viral (due to capillary leak). Treatment is hydration of the patient.

questions.text: A 28 year old male was admitted to a ward with the diagnosis Budd- Chiari syndrome. He also had episodes of epistaxis, and easy bruising for a long time. Lab investigations revealed- Hb- 17 gm%, TLC- 5,700/mm3, and PLT- 1,70,000/mm3. Further investigation revealed increased RBC mass and decreased EPO levels. Which of the following clinical features from the given options are not present in these patients considering the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Isolated diastolic hypertension. In the given clinical scenario, the patient with a diagnosis of Budd Chiari syndrome with elevated Hb level and subnormal EPO level. The clinical diagnosis will be polycythemia vera. In PV, there is systolic hypertension which is a marker of elevated red cell mass. Other clinical features will be Vertigo, tinnitus, headache, visual disturbances due to hyperviscosity because of erythrocytosis. Other features like hepatic vein thrombosis, digital ischemia, easy bruising, epistaxis, acid-peptic disease etc can occur. Increased wbc. mast cell proliferation.causes release of histamine —Acquagenic pruritus. Increased platelets may have the risk of Thrombosis. Acquired von Willebrand disease. (Bleeding/Epistaxis can be seen).

questions.text: A Male patient attended your OPD with complaints of fever, weight loss and sweats. He complains of easy fatigability and pain in the abdomen. On examination, splenomegaly was present. Investigations, Hb- 7.8 gm% with leukocytosis. Her P/S showed the following picture. What will be the status of BCR-ABL and JAK-2 mutation in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. BCR-ABL: absent, JAK-2 mutation- present
questions.explanation:
Solution:

BCR-ABL: absent, JAK-2 mutation- present In the given clinical scenario, the patient with complaints of fever, weight loss and sweats, abdominal pain with splenomegaly. Lab investigation showing anemia with leuko erythrocytosis P/S showing tear drop RBC with precursor Erythroid cells suggest the diagnosis of primary myelofibrosis. In these patients, JAK-2 mutation is present in 30-50% of patients and BCR-ABL negative. Hence, the correct answer will be option C.

questions.text: A 58 year old male patient with severe anemia and hepatosplenomegaly was referred from PHC to a higher center for management. A peripheral smear of the patient revealed teardrop RBC, nucleated RBC and giant platelets. Bone marrow aspiration was planned which failed on multiple attempts. What will be the finding of the B/M biopsy if it is done?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

D. In the given clinical scenario, a patient with severe anemia and hepatosplenomegaly with a P/S smear showing teardrop RBC, nucleated RBC and erythroid precursor, the B/M biopsy finding will be seen as fibrosis in the marrow with dry tap due to obliteration of marrow as indicated in image D.

questions.text: A 62 year old male patient presented with headache and dizziness for a month now. During further history taking, he also mentions that he sometimes feels numbness in his fingers of both the hands. His lab investigation reveals- Hb- 8.9 gm%, PLT- 5.2 lakh. B/M biopsy revealed megakaryocytic hyperplasia. Which of the following agents is the drug of choice for the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hydroxyurea In the given clinical scenario, the patient with headache and dizziness along with anemia and elevated platelet count and B/M biopsy showing megakaryocytic hyperplasia points towards the diagnosis of Essential thrombocytosis. The agent of choice in this condition is hydroxyurea which is a platelet lowering agent. Low dose aspirin for prophylaxis for patients<60 years without thrombosis. Interferon ά is used as a first line agent in patients 40 -60 years. Hydroxy urea is as First Line choice i n patients aged>60 years with Essential Thrombocytosis.

questions.text: A 62 year old male with severe anemia and massive splenomegaly showed the following findings on P/S. bone marrow aspiration was attempted but failed and a bone marrow biopsy was done. Which of the following mediators are responsible for the bone marrow finding in the given patient for the condition he is suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both B and C In the given clinical scenario, the patient with massive splenomegaly and anemia with P/S showing tear drop RBC along with precursor cells of erythroid lineage with B/M aspiration giving dry tap suggest the diagnosis of primary myelofibrosis. The factors responsible for marrow fibrosis are due to the elevation of TGF-B as well as PDGF. A major role is of increased TGF-B which results in obliteration of the bone marrow. Hence, the answer to this question will be option D.

questions.text: You are posted in the medicine ward during your internship where you were responsible for investigations of a 54 year old male patient who has symptoms of fever, and weight loss. options.label: B

In the given question, the statement which is correct for the wrt leukemoid reaction is that the reactive neutrophil count will be >50,000/mm3. questions.text: A 21 year old male with the presence of HB level- 17 gm%, Hct- 50%, TLC- 6,000/mm3 during his regular check-up is now presented with the following finding as shown in the image. Which of the following other complications can be associated with this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Post polycythemia development of acute leukaemia.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above. In the given question, the patient with the presence of elevated Hb and presenting with erythromelalgia as given in the image, the most likely diagnosis will be polycythemia vera. The complication which can develop in this patient will be – Gout – hyperuricemia due to increased cell turnover. Signs of thrombocytosis like digital ischemia, easy bruising, epistaxis It can also lead to the development of post-polycythemia myelofibrosis. PV can also transform into acute leukemias. Hence, the correct answer for this question will be option D.

questions.text: A young male patient came to OPD with complaints of itching after taking a shower, pain in the extremities and numbness. His blood investigation was done which revealed the following findings - Hb- 17.2gm%, TLC- 5,600/mm3, PLT- 1,69,000 /mm3. Further, his RBC mass was also elevated and EPO levels were reduced. His B/M biopsy was revealed which showed hypercellular marrow with trilineage growth. Which of the following drugs is appropriate for the treatment of this patient and what is the mechanism of action of the drug?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ruxolinitib, MOA- JAK-2 inhibitor. In the clinical scenario, the male patient fits into the criteria for polycythemia vera. His features of aquagenic pruritus, elevated Hb and B/M showing hypercellularity. The appropriate drug for this condition will be JAK-2 kinase inhibitor i.e. ruxolitinib.

questions.text: You were asked by your junior resident to collect the P/S smear and bone marrow examination report of three patients. The results of patient was given below- Mr Sameer- peripheral smear showed tear drop RBC, precursor cells and giant platelets. Ms seema- B/M biopsy report showed hypercellular marrow with trilineage growth. Mr Raghu- B/M showed megakaryocytic hyperplasia. Which of the following patients will have Philadelphia chromosome-positive?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above. Mr Sameer- Mr Sameer- peripheral smear showed teardrop RBC, precursor cells and giant platelets- diagnosis will be myelofibrosis. Ms Seema- B/M biopsy report showed hypercellular marrow with trilineage growth. The diagnosis will be polycythemia vera. Raghu- B/M showed megakaryocytic hyperplasia. Diagnosis will be essential thrombocythemia. All 3 options will have Philadelphia chromosome-negative. Philadelphia positive is seen in CML Hence, the correct answer will be option D.
